metadata.title: Biomedical and bioactive engineered nanomaterials for targeted tumor photothermal therapy_ A review

sections.text:
Contents lists available at ScienceDirect
Materials Science & Engineering C
journal homepage: www.elsevier.com/locate/msec
Review
Biomedical and bioactive engineered nanomaterials for targeted tumor photothermal therapy: A review
Wenfeng Weia,1, Xiaoyuan Zhangb,1, Shan Zhanga, Gang Weic,⁎, Zhiqiang Sua,⁎
a State Key Laboratory of Chemical Resource Engineering, Beijing Key Laboratory of Advanced Functional Polymer Composites, Beijing University of Chemical Technology, 100029 Beijing, China b Faculty of Physics and Astronomy, Friedrich-Schiller University Jena, D-07743 Jena, Germany c Faculty of Production Engineering, University of Bremen, D-28359 Bremen, Germany
A R T I C L E I N F O
Keywords: Tumor Biomedical Engineered nanomaterials Biomedical applications Photothermal therapy
A B S T R A C T
Currently, a lot of efforts have been applied to diagnosis and treat tumors through the fabrication of highlyefficient and multi-functional nanomaterials. Superior to other methods, photothermal therapy (PTT) has been demonstrated as a noninvasive, controllable, and targeted strategy to eliminate tumor cells. The use of functional biomedical and bioactive nanomaterials can enhance the photothermal performances and meanwhile integrate with favorable functions, by taking into account their risk assessments. In this review, novel engineered photothermal nanomaterials, such as noble metal-, carbon-, semiconductor-, and organic molecule-based PTT agents, as well as their targeted biomedical applications were summarized and discussed comprehensively. Particularly, the latest advances of not only the conventional nanomaterials, but also the newly-discovered alternatives, like Au-Ag, graphdiyne, and selenides, were introduced. Besides the benefits, the risks and other implications of novel PTT agents were recorded and evaluated. Moreover, the potential applications of nanomaterials in targeted and multi-functional PTT treatments, which served as foundations and directions for future PTT approaches developments, were stated. Depending on the urgency and boosting demands for tumor treatments, novel engineering advancements of techniques, not limited to PTT and nanomaterials, are prerequisites in the history of medical development.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
The tumor has been one of the major threats to human health for centuries [1]. According to the International Agency for Research on Cancer (IARC) report, the new cases of tumor in 2018 are 18.1 million and the death number for the tumor has been 9.6 million [2]. The current treatments for tumor limited mainly in surgery, chemotherapies, and radiotherapies [3,4]. It was known that surgery alone cannot remove all tumor cells from the body system completely. The other two methods can effectively kill the tumor cells, while normal cell and organ will be hurt prominently at the same time [5]. To overcome these problems, many researchers have been working on photothermal therapy (PTT), which exerts fewer side effects on organ systems [6–8]. For instance, Luo et al. reviewed recent progress on the design and fabrication of functional 2D nanomaterials for the tumor treatment including drug delivery, photodynamic therapy, and PTT [9]. Chen and co-workers summarized the current status of employing nanomaterials
for PTT. Moreover, the mechanisms of the photothermal effect and various factors affecting photothermal performance were discussed [10].
It was reported that tumor cells could be effectively killed when the site temperature is above 42 °C [11]. PTT is an emerging method for the treatment of the tumor by thermal ablation of tumor cells [11]. In PTT process, the temperature evolution of the tumor site is caused by the media to convert the light energy to heat energy, and the media is named as a photosensitizer. Moreover, the elevated temperature could kill tumor cells while avoiding significant side effects on normal cells. This method works because tumor cells have a lower heat tolerance than normal cells. Specifically, the photosensitizers concentrate on the site of the lesion at first. Then the lesion was irradiated with near-infrared (NIR) light. Subsequently, photosensitizers will engender lots of heat to ablate the tumor cells [12,13]. Owing to the superior tissue penetration ability and remote control, NIR light has been extensively utilized for PTT [14]. Moreover, it has high-resolution adjustability in

T
both time and space so that precise control can be performed [3,15]. The photosensitizer for PTT possessed a suitable band gap of NIR light, so as to be capable of responding to NIR light stimuli [1]. Ideal photosensitizers should have a strong absorbance in the NIR region and could efficiently convert the absorbed NIR light energy into heat. Besides, it should be low-toxic or nontoxic and exhibit excellent biocompatibility. Recently, various kinds of nanomaterials with strong NIR absorbance have displayed great promise in PTT for tumor treatment, such as gold nanomaterials [16], graphene nanosheets [17], and copper sulfide nanoparticles [18]. These nanomaterials could be used as photosensitizer because they possess high photothermal conversion efficiency. For example, Lan et al. summarized recent advances in using nanoscale metal-organic frameworks as nanoparticle photosensitizers for PTT [19]. What's more, Zhang and co-workers reviewed the PTT by using the nanocomposites composed of inorganic nanoparticles and polymers as photosensitizers, and provided a theory that the extinction coefficient and photothermal conversion efficiency were two main factors to evaluate the photothermal performance of nanocomposites in vitro [20].
In order to explain high photothermal conversion efficiencies of photothermal materials doped with nanomaterials, it is imperative to understand the working principles of the photothermal materials. As we all know, nanomaterial is a typical mesoscopic system, which has surface effect, small size effect, and macro quantum tunnel effect [21,22]. Meanwhile, the optical, thermal, electrical, magnetic, mechanical, and chemical properties of nanomaterials are significantly different from bulk solids [23–25]. Previous studies have proved that the metal-, carbon-, and semiconductor-based nanomaterials can be used as photosensitizers in PTT system. The reason for inorganic photosensitizers is
that these materials possess optical phenomenon known as localized surface resonance (LSPR). After absorbing the NIR light, the electrons out of the photosensitizers have obvious plasma resonance effect. Therefore, they can generate obviously thermal effect to heat the surrounding medium and make the temperature rises rapidly [26], indicating these nanomaterials have strong absorption under the NIR light. For example, Manikandan et al. studied the photothermal effect of platinum nanoparticles (Pt NPs) with sizes ranging from 5 to 6 nm [27]. It was found that Pt NPs could generate a 9 °C increase in temperature and further could be used as ablation agents for photothermal ablation of Neuro 2A cells. In another work, Elbialy et al. developed multifunctional magnetic gold nanoparticles (Au NPs) with diameter of 29 ± 4 nm, the as-prepared nanoparticles was confirmed to be effective as agent for PTT by histopathological examination and immunohistochemical studies [28].
Besides, organic materials can also be applied for efficient photothermal conversion. This is due to that organic molecules contain a large π-conjugated system. This structure determines that the organic materials could absorb the light energy in the range of 600 to 850 nm. After absorbing NIR light, the energy of the electron increases and the electronic transition occurs from the ground state to the single-excited state. In general, this singlet excited-state only with nanosecond lifetime. However, the unpaired non-parallel electrons are very unstable. When the electrons fall from the single-excited state to the ground state, the extra energy is released as light and heat energy. Therefore, the organic materials exhibit photothermal conversion capability [3]. For instance, Dai et al. synthesized uniform polypyrrole (PPy) nanoparticles with an average size of 46 nm via aqueous dispersion polymerization. The temperature of the aqueous solution with a concentration of
30 μgml−1 increased from 21.3 to 55.8 °C upon NIR laser irradiation (808 nm, 2W) [29].
Therefore, nanomaterials with photothermal efficiency have attracted great attention due to their selectivity and non-invasive attributes. In this review, we introduce kinds of novel photothermal nanomaterials and their biomedical applications, including noble metalbased nanomaterials of Au, Ag and Au-Ag nanomaterials, carbon-based nanomaterials of carbon quantum dots, carbon nanotubes, graphene sheets and graphdiyne; semiconductor-based nanomaterials of sulfides, oxides and selenides; organic molecular-based nanomaterials of NIR dyes and conductive polymers. Notably, we focus on the synthesis and characteristics of photothermal conversion materials of the above photothermal nanomaterials. Moreover, the applications of photothermal nanomaterials are also presented and discussed. Finally, the challenges and prospects of photothermal materials in the rapidly developing scientific research area are given.

sections.heading: 2. Chemical and biological engineering of nanomaterials for photosensitizers
sections.text: Many efforts have been performed to develop biomedical and bioactive nanomaterials with highly efficient and targeted NIR thermal conversion, in order to improve the NIR light-to-heat conversion efficiency. At present, there are mainly four types of photothermal nanomaterials (as indicated in Fig. 1), which can be used as photosensitizers for PTT,. They are classified as noble metal-, carbon-, semiconductor-, and, organic molecule-based nanomaterials, respectively.

sections.heading: 2.1. Engineering of nanomaterials for PTT
sections.text:
Nanomaterials, with one dimension between 1 and 100 nm at least, possess unique properties because of small size effect. It is reported that nanomaterials with rational designing can be used for PTT [30,31]. According to the previous work, it can be classified into chemical and biological modification by engineering of nanomaterials for PTT [32,33].
Biological modification, i.e. coating biocompatible materials on nanomaterials, has attracted increasing attention [34]. To facilitate PTT, the coated materials possessing the ability of NIR adsorption and well biocompatibility to modify nanomaterials are important. In general, biomolecules modify nanoparticles by chemical bonds, hydrogen bonds, Au-eS bonds, and so on [35,36]. On the one hand, these biomolecules can improve the biocompatibility of photothermal materials. On the other hand, molecules with recognition characteristics can also target tumor cells at the same time, thereby improving the efficiency of PTT. For example, Zhou et al. designed a platform of aptamer-functionalized Fe3O4@carbon@doxorubicin (Apt-Fe3O4@C@DOX) NPs for chemo-photothermal therapy [32]. In this platform, the AptFe3O4@C@DOX NPs with a diameter of roughly 90 nm and exhibited strong ability to transform 808 nm NIR light into heat energy for both photothermal ablation of tumor cells and photothermal drug release. More importantly, the aptamers served as markers for tumor cells targeting for Apt-Fe3O4@C@DOX NPs. It is proven that the tumor cells were targeted by the Apt-Fe3O4@C@DOX NPs both in vitro and in vivo. Then, the tumor cells were effectively destroyed by photothermal and chemical destructions. Gao and co-workers coated a modified tri-block peptide with a sequence of CCVVGRKKRRQRRRPQGGPLGVEKEKEKEK on gold nanorods (GNR@PEP NPs) [37]. Gold nanorods (GNR) is a typical NIR photothermal agent and its hydrophilic diameter is quite large of 120 nm. Thus, tri-block functional peptide was used to protect GNR and achieve long blood circulation time and efficient accumulation at tumor sites. It was found that GNR@PEP NPs showed excellent anti-tumor ability under NIR light. In another work, Zhang et al. reported a virus-surface-mimicking nanotechnology by decorating geneentrapped polymeric nanoparticles with clustered gold nanoparticles (Au NPs) [38]. This strategy offered a special method to realize the
efficient PTT by hyperthermia which was generated by AuNPs in NIR region. It was excited that the Au NPs entrapped with DNA by this hybridization approach, demonstrating outstanding potency for the NIR photothermal therapy in tumorous HeLa cells.
In addition to biological modification, engineering nanomaterials for PTT by chemical modification is another commonly used method. Unlike the biomaterials with well biocompatibility that are used for biological modification, chemical modification usually utilizes chemical materials with some specific properties to improve the photothermal conversion efficiency, which is the ability to combine with other molecular and many other optical or biological properties [39,40]. For instance, Suo et al. developed a pH-sensitive oxidized hyaluronic acid-decorated dihydroxyphenyl/hydrazide bifunctionalized hydroxyethyl chitosan (DHHC)-GNR conjugate (DOX-DHHC-GNR) for PTT [33]. Firstly, dihydroxyphenylation and hydrazidation of hydroxyethyl chitosan were used for preparing DHHC through carbodiimide reaction and click chemistry, respectively. Therefore, the conjugate was obtained by chemically bonding DHHC onto GNR via Aucatechol bonds. Meanwhile, DOX was loaded onto the conjugate via an acid-labile hydrazone linkage. The cell viability decreased to 34.6% of tumor cells which were incubated with DOX-DHHC-GNRAH for 24 h and then under NIR irradiation (808 nm, 2.0W/cm2) for 10min. The effective killing of tumor cells was attributed to the excellent photothermal conversion ability of gold nanorods and the killing ability of DOX and other chemical molecules. In another work, Shen and colleagues designed a new hybrid nanoplatform of polydopamine (PDA)coated and perfluorohexane (PFH)-filled gold core/hollow mesoporous silica shell (Au@mSiO2-PFH-PDA) nanoparticles [41]. Au NPs with photothermal conversion ability was used for PTT and computed tomography. At the same time, the PDA shell and the filled PFH were used for photoacoustic. It was found that the PDA coating not only improved the stability and biocompatibility of Au@mSiO2-PFH-PDA nanoparticles, but also improved effective photothermal imaging and PTT of tumors to inhibit the occurrence of tumor metastasis. In a word, all the above description and examples prove that the reasonable biological or chemical engineering of nanoparticles is beneficial for PPT of tumors.

sections.heading: 2.2. Noble metal-based nanomaterials for PTT
sections.text: Noble metal plasmonic nanomaterials, such as Au and Ag NPs, are extensively utilized as photosensitizers [42,43]. These nanomaterials provided a versatile and multifaceted platform for a broad range of biomedical applications in tumor diagnosis and therapies.

sections.heading: 2.2.1. Au nanomaterials
sections.text:
Au nanomaterials are biologically inert because these materials cannot be oxidized easily [44]. Besides, Au nanomaterials exhibit fascinating optical, electrical, and chemical properties due to their nanoscale structures [45]. More importantly, as one kind of noble metals, Au nanomaterials intrinsically possess LSPR as mentioned previously [46].
Various nanostructures with Au cores have been synthesized, such as Au NPs [47], nanoshells [48], nanorods (NRs) [49], and nanostars [50]. Interestingly, the photothermal conversion efficiency of Au NPs is affected by the diameter. That is because its shape and size may change LSPR peaks and the photothermal efficiency of Au NPs [51]. For example, Jiang et al. reported the changeable photothermal conversion efficiency of Au NPs with variable size [52]. Au NPs with sizes ranging from 5 to 50 nm were fabricated by chemical reduction methods using sodium borohydride, sodium citrate, or hydroquinone as reducing agents. It was showed that as the diameter of Au NPs decreased from 50.09 ± 2.34 to 4.98 ± 0.59 nm, the photothermal conversion efficiency increased from 65.0 ± 1.2% to 80.3 ± 0.8%.
Singh et al. loaded Au NPs into the NIR-sensitive liposome curcumin [53]. Therein, liposome curcumin NPs were synthesized by thin film hydration method and then reduction of HAuCl4 occurred in the
presence of liposome curcumin NPs. The as-prepared NPs exhibited a diameter of 100 ± 6.5 nm. When the solution was irradiated under 780 nm NIR laser for 10min, the temperature increased to 60 °C from room temperature.
Synthetic polypeptides and their amphiphilic copolymers have been also used for noble metal NPs modification, owing to their excellent biocompatibility and biodegradability [42]. Yang and colleagues synthesized poly(L‑cysteine)‑b‑poly(ethylene oxide) copolymer@Au (PLCb-PEO@Au) NPs by one-pot photoreduction strategy [47]. The structure of Au NPs presented as irregular polyhedral gold nanocrystals core stabilized by a thin copolymer layer. The diameter of the NPs was about 62 ± 3 nm. It was found that PLC-b-PEO@Au nanoparticles possessed strong NIR absorption, and photothermal conversion efficiency could be 62.1% which was ultrahigh. Moreover, the temperature of the PLCb-PEO@Au NPs solutions (1 mg/mL) had an elevation of 30.8 °C under 808 nm laser irradiation.
In another case, Pan et al. synthesized a new PTT system by modifying GNR with TAT-peptide (denoted as GNRs-NLS) [54], as illustrated in Fig. 2A. It was found that the mean length and width of the prepared GNR were approximately 40.5 ± 2.1 nm and 10.5 ± 1.7 nm, respectively (Fig. 2B). Due to the specific recognition of TAT peptide to HeLa cells, the as-fabricated GNRs-NLS facilitated the intranuclear localization of GNR-NLS in HeLa cells. Interestingly, the nuclear matrix was one of the most thermolabile structures in cells, so that the PTT with GNRs-NLS as photosensitizers was realized under lower laser irradiation intensity [56,57]. Upon the NIR irradiation (808 nm, 0.2W/ cm2), GNRs-NLS solutions generated a lower temperature rise by 10.6 °C in 5min, and most of tumor cells incubated with GNRs-NLS were damaged or dead. This demonstrated that the GNR-NLS photothermal system could have a significant improvement in thermal ablation of tumor cells even the irradiation density was about 1/10 of normal (808 nm, 2W/cm2).
Yang and co-workers prepared Au NPs with a diameter of 4 nm by reducing the chloroauric acid (Fig. 2C) [55]. The as-prepared Au NPs were attached to the mesoporous silica nanoparticles (MSN) via AueS bonds. And doxorubicin (DOX) as the model of the drug was loaded into
MSN by electrostatic interaction. The final nanosystem of DOX/MSNAu NPs with a diameter of 250.6 nm and was described in Fig. 2D. Interestingly, when NIR laser (808 nm, 2W) was applied to irradiate the DOX/MSN-Au NPs (50 μg/mL) suspension for 3min, the temperature of the suspension could reach 47 °C from room temperature. The temperature increase was generated by the conversion of the NIR light energy, which was absorbed by the Au NPs, to heat. In addition, the increased temperature weakened the electrostatic interaction between DOX and of DOX/MSN-Au NPs. This facilitated the NIR-triggered DOX release.

sections.heading: 2.2.2. Ag NPs
sections.text:
As another precious metal material, Ag NPs have been reported to own excellent physical, electrical, and antimicrobial properties [58]. In addition, Ag NPs show great advantages in comparison with Au NPs, Pd NPs, and other metal-based nanomaterials because Ag NPs require simplified synthesize procedure and lower cost [59]. Unfortunately, Ag NPs have poor biocompatibility owing to their oxidizability. Therefore, the cytotoxicity of human cells may occur. Besides, it was found that the size and morphology of Ag NPs can directly affect their plasma resonance characteristics and thus the plasmonic performance [60]. Up to now, there have been few reports on the applications of Ag NPs alone as photothermal materials.
To fabricate Ag NP-based photosensitizers, some researchers employed bovine serum albumin (BSA) to modify Ag NPs. BSA, an important blood protein, contains sufficient amino acid functional groups, such as imidazolyl groups in histidine residues and thiol groups in cysteine residues. These functional groups allow BSA coordinated with Ag ions well [43]. In a typical study, Cui and co-workers synthesized Ag nanodots (AgND) with the help of BSA by a biomineralization method (Fig. 3A) [61]. Biomineralization is a mild synthetic method by the reaction between metal ions and functional groups on proteins [63]. Here, the BSA solution was firstly mixed with AgNO3 under vigorous stirring. Then the pH value of the mixture solution was regulated up to above 12 by adding NaOH solution. And later the reaction of some amino acid residues of BSA and Ag+ would occur in 80 °C water bath.
The mean diameter size of the AgND was 5.80 ± 0.5 nm and the AgND solution retained excellent water solubility. It was found that the ratio of Ag+ ions to BSA determined the corresponding optical and photothermal properties. With the increasing ratio, the size of AgND increased largely, which was confirmed by the intensity increase of the absorption spectra at 420 nm (Fig. 3B). In particular, when the ratio changed from 1.32 to 52.8, the temperature increased in AgND solution changed less than 2 °C and 14 °C under the irradiation of 808 nm NIR laser at 1.0W/cm2.
In another work, Wang et al. combined the indocyanine green (ICG), folic acid (FA), and Janus-type Ag mesoporous silica nanoparticles (JNPs) together and fabricated photosensitizers (FA-JNPs@ICG) for PTT via a modified sol-gel method [64]. Upon NIR irradiation (808 nm, 1W/cm2), the temperature of FA-JNPs@ICG aqueous reached 51.6 °C from room temperature.

sections.heading: 2.2.3. Au-Ag NPs
sections.text:
Very recently, some researches focused on the photothermal performance of combined Au and Ag NPs. For instance, Chen et al. investigated the photothermal conversion of bimetallic Au-Ag NPs using sodium citrate thermal reduction method [65]. The as-prepared Au-Ag bimetallic NPs with an average size of 29 ± 7 nm, different from those of Au (10 ± 2 nm) and Ag NPs (38 ± 7 nm), respectively. Results showed when the volume fraction of the Au-Ag bimetallic NPs and the Au-Ag blended NPs were the same, the temperature increase of Au-Ag bimetallic NPs nanofluid (41.37% of initial temperature) was higher than the Au-Ag blended NPs nanofluid (31.41% of initial temperature). This phenomenon was ascribed to the wider absorption band of Au-Ag bimetallic NPs than that of the Au-Ag blended NPs, which was caused by synergistic effects of Au-Ag bimetallic NPs.
The designed particle structures, such as core-shell structure, enhanced the PTT properties of Au-Ag bimetallic NPs significantly. Li
et al. prepared branched Au-Ag NPs with Au-rich core and Ag branches by galvanic replacement [66]. Galvanic replacement was a method for preparing novel nanostructures via the reaction between sacrificial metal NPs and less active metal ions. In this study, the AuIII was reduced by the Ag seeds (50–60 nm) and then collected on the surface of Ag seeds. At the same time, the Ag0 was oxidized to AgI ion and dissolved in the solution to produce pure Au or hollow Au-Ag nanostructures. The obtained NPs exhibited a diameter of ca. 100 nm. However, the structural stability of branched NPs was usually poor due to that the generated heat from the photothermal effect of Au-Ag NPs could melt the anisotropic nanostructures into bulk aggregation under NIR laser irradiation.
In order to improve the structural stability of the branched Au-Ag NPs, polydopamine (PDA) was coated on the Au-Ag NPs through the strong binding affinity of catechol functional groups [66]. PDA received significant attention because of its unique adhesive ability, good biocompatibility, and easy bioconjugation [67,68]. Moreover, PDA was found possessing strong absorption in the NIR region and exhibiting excellent photothermal conversion ability. The obtained core-shell structured Au-Ag@PDA NPs displayed size of 135 nm. And the thickness of the PDA shell could be controlled by altering the feed amount of dopamine. In detail, as increasing dopamine from 100 to 600 μL, the shell thickness gradually increased from 6 to 34 nm. Upon NIR laser irradiation, the photothermal conversion efficiency of the Au-Ag@PDA NPs with 10 nm PDA shell was 61.4%. While this efficiency increased to 72.9% for the Au-Ag@PDA NPs with 34 nm PDA shell. It was concluded that the thicker the PDA shell was, the better photothermal performance of the NPs. This phenomenon further demonstrated that PDA shell was helpful to enhance the photothermal performance of branched Au-Ag NPs.
With different method, Zeng and co-workers synthesized 3,3′-diethylthiatricarbocyanine iodide (DTTC)-coupled Agcore@Aushell
nanosystem (Ag@Au-DTTC) by a two-step coupling method shown in Fig. 3C [62]. Au nanostars grew on the surface of Ag NPs (32 nm) to form Agcore@Aushell nanosystem (72 nm), as shown in Fig. 3D. After coupled DTTC, the final Ag@Au-DTTC nanostars reached a size of 74 nm. The photothermal conversion efficiency of as-prepared Ag@AuDTTC nanostars was up to 79.01%. This number was much higher than Au NRs, Au nanocages, and other polymer photothermal nanomaterials [69–71].

sections.heading: 2.3. Carbon nanomaterials-based hybrids
sections.text: The carbon-based nanomaterials, such as carbon quantum dot (CQDs), carbon nanotubes (CNTs) and reduced graphene oxides (rGO), are capable of absorbing broad-spectrum light from ultraviolet (λ=10–400 nm) to near-infrared wavelengths (λ=700–1000 nm). Specifically, carbon-based nanomaterials have presented great potential as PTT materials due to their NIR absorbance, abundant functional groups, and large specific surface area. Therefore, the carbon-based nanomaterials are classified as one kind of excellent photosensitizer materials [72].

sections.heading: 2.3.1. Carbon quantum dots
sections.text:
Carbon quantum dots (CQDs) are ultra-small carbon NPs, whose diameter is not> 10 nm. Due to the ultrasmall size and hydrophilicity, CQDs possess excellent water dispersibility, unique optical features, good biocompatibility, and low biotoxicity. They have been extensively applied in bioimaging, drug delivery, and light-emitting devices [73,74]. Bao and co-workers prepared thiol-polyethylene glycol (thiolPEG2k) modified copper/carbon quantum dot-crosslinked nanospheres (CuCD NSs) by a novel and facile preparation method [75]. In detail, the CQDs (average size of 3.4 ± 5 nm) were synthesized using o‑phenylenediamine and L‑cysteine by hydrothermal treatment. Then CuCD NSs (average size: 23.4 nm) were obtained through simply mixing of Cu2+ solution and CD solution. Later, CuCD NSs solution and thiolPEG2k were mixed to improve the stability of CuCD NSs. The average diameter of resulted PEG-coated CuCD NSs was 45.7 ± 12.8 nm. According to the previous work, the photothermal conversion efficiency of the NSs was 41.3% (808 nm, 2W/cm2) [76]. In addition to the fluorescence ability of CDs, the CuCD NSs achieved imaging-guided photothermal tumor therapy.
To further improve the photothermal efficiencies of CQDs, chitosan was utilized as a precursor [73]. Chitosan is a natural polymer, polyhydroxyaldehyde, which exhibits nontoxic, biodegradable, and nonimmunogenic properties [77]. In the work of Wang et al., a system of combined chitosan and CQDs (CCHNs, in Fig. 4A) was successfully synthesized via in-situ cross-linked in aqueous solution [78]. This special system can be achieved by hydrogen-bonds between chitosan bearing -eNH2/-eOH groups and CQDs bearing -eOH/-eCOOH groups. Fig. 4B showed that the CCHNs possessed a spherical morphology with an average diameter of approximately 65 nm. Notably, DOX molecules were loaded through π-π stacking and electrostatic attractions onto CCHNs. From Fig. 4C and D, the release rate of DOX molecules was slow and steady after the initial fast release without NIR light. However, the DOX release rate was significantly enhanced by 20% under NIR irradiation. It was concluded that the local heat produced by the photothermal effect of CDs in CCHNs weakened the DOXCCHNs interactions (e.g., hydrogen bonding and π-π stacking) and increased the mobility of DOX molecules.
Many researchers have also devoted effort into fabricating magnetic nanomaterials with the photothermal property, which consisted of magnetic NPs and CQDs. Zhang and co-workers prepared a core-shell NPs whose core was iron nitride and shell was CQDs (FeN@CQDs) via hydrothermal method [79]. To be more specific, chitosan was dissolved in a FeCl3·6H2O (0.1M) aqueous solution for 4 h. Then mixed it with solid, sodium acrylate and a mixture of ethylene glycol and diethylene glycol was placed in a beaker and stirred for several minutes. Finally,
the FeN@CQDs was obtained by the react of the mixture at 200 °C for 10 h. The prepared FeN@CQDs were well-dispersed in water and approximately spherical in shape with an average size of 6.2 nm. Under continuous NIR laser irradiation of FeN@CQDs solutions (200mg/mL) in PBS solution within 8min, the temperature increased by 27.6 °C. While the control PBS solution only increased less than 5.8 °C from room temperature. This result showed the great potential of this nanocomposite as photothermal agents in PTT. However, several in vitro and in vivo studies indicated that magnetic CQDs are intrinsically cytotoxic, because they may release free radicals of heavy metals from the CQDs core into the bloodstream [79,80].

sections.heading: 2.3.2. Graphene nanosheets
sections.text:
Graphene nanomaterials have attracted abundant attention due to their large specific surface area, excellent electrical property, and thermal conductivity [81–83]. Generally, graphene, with chemical inertness, is modified by introducing various reactive groups for extensive applications, especially reduced graphene oxide (rGO) [25,84]. Meanwhile, it has been proved that the photothermal efficiency of rGO is higher than that of graphene oxide (GO) [85,86]. This phenomenon expanded the bio-applications of rGO as an effective drug carrier in tumor cells [7,87].
Yang and colleagues developed an aptamer-Au NPs-hybridized graphene oxide (Apt-AuNPs-GO) system (Fig. 5A) [88]. Therein, GO was synthesized using an improved Hummers' method [89] and the average sizes of the single-layered GOs were approximately 300 nm. Au NPs (13 nm diameter) were prepared by reducing AuCl4− using citrate ions. Then the aptamer molecules directly interacted with the Au NPs to form Apt-AuNPs (15 nm), attaching oligo-S units onto the Au NPs surfaces. Later on, Apt-AuNPs-GO was obtained by mixing the Apt-AuNPs with GO in a sodium phosphate solution (5mM, pH 7.4) for 1 h. Because of the strong Au−-eS bond between Au NPs and Apt, as well as the π-π stacking between the multivalent nucleobase of aptamers and GO, the stability of this nanosystem was improved significantly. Under continuous irradiation of 808 nm NIR light with a power intensity of 3W, Apt-AuNPs-GO nanoparticles displayed photothermal conversion efficiency of 25.4%.
In another work, Otari and colleagues designed a graphene oxide with gold nanoparticles and then decorated with nisin peptides (NAuNP-rGO, Fig. 5B) nanocomposite in an autoclave by one-step synthesis method [90]. Nisin is a thermostable peptide and it has antimicrobial activities against gram-positive microorganisms [92]. For GO, nisin played the role as a reducing agent. In order to test the photothermal property of NAuNP-rGO, breast tumor cells, incubated with 10 μg/mL NAu-rGO nanocomposite, were irradiated for one day by NIR laser. It was found that the survival rate of breast tumor cells was< 20%. This demonstrated that NAuNP-rGO nanocomposite exhibited high potential as NIR photosensitizer.

sections.heading: 2.3.3. Carbon nanotubes
sections.text:
CNTs consist of sp2 carbon sheets rolled into single- or multi-walled tubes [93]. CNTs were reported to possess remarkable electrical, mechanical, and thermal properties because of their nanostructures [94]. It was also found that CNTs are highly efficient absorbers of NIR, and can rapidly transfer electronic excitations into molecular vibration energies and induce heat [95,96]. With these properties, CNTs and modified CNTs have been utilized as photothermal agents [97–99].
One typical example was SWNT/PNIPAM composite gel, fabricated by Fujigaya and co-workers via a free radical polymerization [100]. PNIPAM is one kind of well-known thermo-responsive materials, which show phase transition triggered by temperature stimuli. Upon the lower critical solution temperature (LCST) of 32 °C, because of the drastic change of hydrophobicity and hydrogen bond of PNIPAM, an obvious phase transition from swelling state of hydrophilic to shrinking state of hydrophobic substance of PNIPAM would occur [101]. Therefore, it was found that the morphology of SWNT/PNIPAM gel obviously shrank
under NIR laser irradiation (1064 nm, 210mW after 15 s), distinct from PNIPAM gel. This phenomenon could be ascribed to that the SWNT absorbed NIR energy and converted it into heat. Thus, the local heating increased the temperature of the water in and around the gel, thereby achieved the phase transition temperature of the PNIPAM.
In order to enhance the photothermal property of CNTs, Song et al. designed a novel system based on Au NPs-coated CNT ring (CNTR@AuNP) [91]. In this system, CNTR was utilized as a template and the surface attached redox-active polymer of poly(4‑vinylphenol) (PvPH) was the reducing agent, as shown in Fig. 5C and D. It was observed that CNTR@AuNPs nanocomposite exhibited much stronger Raman and photoacoustic (PA) signal and higher photothermal effect than single CNTR. Specifically, the extinction intensity of this nanocomposite was about 120 times than that of CNTR under 808 nm NIR light, and the SERS signal was about 110-fold higher than that of CNTR. Furthermore, the highest photothermal conversion efficiency of the CNTR@AuNP was calculated to be 76%. The high photothermal conversion efficiency might own to the strong interparticle plasmonic of CNTR coupling with the AuNP nanoshell.

sections.heading: 2.3.4. Graphdiyne
sections.text:
Graphdiyne (GDY) has been synthesized via a homocoupling reaction using hexaethy nylbenzene on the surface of copper since 2010 [102]. It is a novel 2D carbon material and possesses multiple conjugated electronic structures. This is due to that it has not only benzene rings composed of sp2-hybridized carbon atoms but also acetylene units composed of sp-hybridized carbon atoms [103]. Meanwhile, GDY exhibits a tunable band gap from 0.14 eV to 1.22 eV by changing the number of layers and manner of stacking. With these unique properties, GDY has been widely used in energy and biomedical fields [104]. Last
but not least, considering the photothermal conversion ability of GDY in NIR region, it can also be utilized as a photosensitizer [105].
In the work of Li and coauthors, GDY was obtained by ultrasonic and centrifugation. The GDY was further modified by PEG via hydrophobic and electrostatic interactions (Fig. 6A) [105]. From the SEM image of GDY-PEG in Fig. 6B, the morphology of GDY-PEG presented to be thin nanosheets with occasional folds and aggregation. The hydrodynamic size of GDY-PEG was 360 ± 6.5 nm. The GDY-PEG solution displayed a broad absorption band from UV (λ=10 nm) to NIR (λ=700– to 100 nm) regions, which was similar to other 2D layered materials, such as graphene oxide (GO) [106]. Notably, its mass extinction coefficient was approximately three times higher than that of GO. Interestingly, the temperature of the GDY-PEG aqueous solution increased more rapidly when prolonging the irradiation time under 808 nm NIR laser and increasing the concentration of graphdiyne-PEG. The photothermal conversion efficiency of GDY-PEG had been calculated to reach 42%, which exceeded other nanomaterials, such as Au NRs (21%) [76,107]. From Fig. 6C, it was clarified that this nanocomposite showed a much higher tumor inhibition rate under NIR irradiation. These results indicated that GDY-PEG nanomaterials have the promising potential ability for PTT nanomaterials.
In another trial by Jin et al., a GDY drug delivery platform was designed for combined photothermal/chemotherapy [108]. This platform consisted of GDY nanosheets and drug molecular of DOX (GDY/ DOX). At first, GDY nanosheets were fabricated by an exfoliation method. Then DOX was loaded on the sheet surface mainly through π-π stacking and electrostatic interactions. The photothermal conversion efficiency of GDY/DOX was 42%, similar to GDY-PEG. This indicated that simple physical interaction affects obviously the photothermal properties of GDY.

sections.heading: 2.4. Semiconductor-based nanomaterials
sections.text:
Semiconductor-based nanomaterials constitute a class of photothermal agents because of their strong absorption in the NIR region [109], such as MoO3-x [110] and WO3-x [111]. Compared with plasmonic noble metal NPs, plasmonic semiconductors greatly reduce the consumption of noble metal NPs and the cytotoxicity to the organisms.
Copper sulfide (CuS) nanomaterials became a new type of photothermal agents due to accessibility, photostability, and low cytotoxicity [112]. CuS is a p-type semiconductor, whose bandgap (1.1 –- 2.0 eV) is dependent on its composition and crystal [23]. Moreover, its nanocrystals (edge size of 150 - 250 nm and thickness of about 30 nm) have been shown to possess strong NIR absorption owing to their LSPR. This effect resulted from the oscillation of the valence band free carriers of this material [113]. Fang et al. obtained CuS NRs by hydrothermal method [114]. Briefly, the sodium thiosulfate and copper sulfate (CuSO4) aqueous solution with molar concentrations of 0.5M reacted at 180 °C for 12 h. The as-prepared CuS/H2O NRs emulsions possessed good photothermal conversion performance. The maximum temperature of the CuS/H2O NRs emulsions reached about 74.44 °C from room temperature. Even the temperature change was obvious, the difficulty of modification on the NRs limited the application of copper chalcogenide semiconductors as PTT agent.
Recently, Chen et al. synthesized a unique CuS-based micelle [115], CuS NPs, which were modified by thermosensitive amphiphilic block copolymers, poly(acrylamide‑acrylonitrile)-PEG. The upper critical solution temperature (UCST) of poly(acrylamide‑acrylonitrile) was slightly higher than human body temperature. Therefore, a burst release of drugs was avoided under room temperature. From the UV visNIR absorption spectrum, it was observed that CuS-based
nanocomposite solution exhibited obviously stronger absorption band in the NIR region than CuS NPs solution. Upon 980 nm laser irradiation (0.75W/cm2), the temperature of the CuS NPs aqueous solution (60 μg/ mL) increased by 18 °C. This data indicated that CuS-based nanocomposites could serve as an efficient photosensitizer for PTT. The temperature elevations of the CuS-based micelle solutions could cause the phase transition of the micelle. It was due to that the temperature of the solution reached the UCST of poly(acrylamide‑acrylonitrile), thereby the hydrophobic-to-hydrophilic phase transition occurred.
In addition to copper-chalcogenide, molybdenum disulfide (MoS2) is one of the two-dimensional transitional metal dichalcogenide nanosheets [118]. The bandgap of MoS2 is adjustable: from an indirect bandgap of 1.2 eV in the bulk to a direct bandgap of 1.8 eV in singlelayer form [119]. Besides, it has outstanding thermal stability and high electrocatalytic activity. It has been widely utilized in the fields of PTT, drug delivery, bioimaging, and so on [119,120]. For instance, Liu and co-workers fabricated hyperbranched polyglycidyl modified MoS2 (MoS2−-HPG) nanocomposite [116]. The structure of HPG was shown in Fig. 7A and B. This work utilized HPG to modify MoS2 nanosheets by absorbing HPG on the MoS2 surface via the multifunctional groups and the branching structure of HPG. The as-prepared MoS2−-HPG nanocomposite displayed high photothermal conversion efficiency of 29.4% (808 nm, 2.0W/cm2).
Another sulfide nanocomposite, silver sulfide (Ag2S) nanocrystal, is a narrow band-gap semiconductor (appr. 1.5 eV) [121]. Yang and his co-workers obtained Ag2S nanodots (Ag2S-NDs) through biomineralization, shown in Fig. 7C and D [117]. In short, human serum albumin (HAS) was mixed with AgNO3 in water. They were stabilized by electrostatic interactions between Ag+ ions and carboxyl groups. The Ag2SNDs exhibited a diameter of 9.8 ± 0.4 nm after 240min growth. The

photothermal conversion efficiency was 35.0%. Besides, the single-layered WS2 nanosheet, is a semiconductor with a band-gap of 1.5 eV. Wang and coworkers proposed a bottom-up strategy for the one-pot hydrothermal and controlled synthesis of surface polyvinyl pyrrolidone (PVP) modified WS2 nanosheets, WS2-PVP [122]. The chelating-coordinating effect between the lone pair electrons of oxygen of PVP carbonyl group and the unoccupied orbital (5d orbitals) of tungsten was the main driving forces of the as-made nanosheets. It was confirmed that the PVP presented a uniform and regular disk shape with a narrow diameter distribution of 115.4 ± 12.2 nm and the thickness of WS2 nanosheets was about 1.1 nm. When the solution of WS2-PVP nanosheets at a concentration of 37.5 ppm under 808 nm laser (1.0W/cm2) for 120 s, the solution temperature rapidly elevated for 21.7 °C. Encouragingly, the WS2-PVP nanosheets possessed excellent photothermal stability performance because the temperature increase amount kept almost the same under 5 cycles continuous laser irradiation.
Transition-metal oxide (TMO) is a promising candidate for PTT agent because it exhibits fascinating properties arising from the unique structure of the outer valence electrons [123]. Yin and colleagues synthesized a molybdenum oxide nanosheets supported silver nanocubes (MoO3-x-Ag) through a solvothermal method [124]. The hydrogen chloride (HCl) was utilized as an effective etchant for size control to obtain Ag nanocubes [125]. Then the MoO3-x-Ag nanosheets were prepared by oxidizing metal molybdenum powders with hydrogen peroxide (H2O2, 30%) and followed by solvothermal treatment in ethanol solution at 160 °C for 12 h [126]. The Ag nanocubes (with an edge length of ca. 50 nm) were uniformly distributed over the flat surface of MoO3-x nanosheets. The edge length of the nanosheets was larger than 300 nm, and the average thickness was below 20 nm. MoO3x nanosheets possessed positive charged flat surface and Ag nanocubes surface was negative charged, confirmed by zeta potential measurement. For this system, electrostatic interaction was assumed to be the driving force in the connection between MoO3-x and Ag nanocubes. When the concentration was 2mg/ml− of Ag and MoO3-x-Ag aqueous suspensions upon 808 nm laser irradiation (0.5W/cm2 for 10min), MoO3-x-Ag solution showed a temperature increased up by 21.5 °C, much larger than that of Ag nanocubes (15.9 °C). This result demonstrated the combination of MoO3-x and Ag nanocubes could enhance the photothermal conversion capability of Ag nanocubes. The reason might be that the heat generated by MoO3-x nanosheets could be diffused to Ag nanocubes through the interface between them.
In another work, Liu et al. established a TiO2-x based nanoplatforms for tumor theranostics therapy [127]. Therein, TiO2 nanospheres were fabricated by a solvothermal method [128]. The mesoporous nonstoichiometric TiO2-x nanospheres were obtained by reducing the TiO2 nanospheres under a hydrogen atmosphere at 500 °C for 1 h. The diameter of the as-prepared TiO2-x nanospheres was 606 nm. From the UV– vis-NIR spectrum of TiO2-x powder samples, the nonstoichiometric TiO2-x displayed high absorption in the NIR region of 800–-1500 nm. The absorbance at 808 nm was about 4-fold of TiO2. It was demonstrated that the nonstoichiometric TiO2-x nanospheres were a splendid NIR absorbing material. Meanwhile, upon 808 nm NIR laser irradiation (1.0W/cm2), the temperature of the nonstoichiometric TiO2-x solutions (1 mg/mL) increased by 24 °C. These phenomena proved that the nonstoichiometric TiO2-x had great potential to be an efficient photosensitizer for PTT.
Bismuth selenide (Bi2Se3) displayed excellent NIR photothermal conversion capability due to the high absorption band at the NIR region [80]. It was reported that nanoscaled Bi2Se3 could be utilized for PTT, photodetection and photoelectrochemical cells [129]. For instance, ultrathin Bi2Se3 nanosheets with a diameter of 31.4 nm and a thickness of 1.7 nm were proven to be an effective photoacoustic imaging agent due to their large extinction coefficient [130]. Zhou et al. first reported a method to fabricate Bi2Se3 nanosheets by a selenite-reducing bacterium [131]. In detail, preincubated Lysinibacillus sp. ZYM-1 bacteria
liquid was injected into 100mL of sterilized tryptic soy broth (TSB) medium, and incubated in an incubator with Na2SeO3 and Bi(NO3)3 at 30 °C with a speed of 150 rpm. After centrifuging, washing, and drying, the Bi2Se3 nanosheets with a diameter of 60 nm and a thickness of 5–6 nm were obtained. When Bi2Se3 solution with a concentration of 26mg/L was exposed under NIR irradiation, the photothermal conversion efficiency of the prepared Bi2Se3 was calculated to be 30.7%. This value indicated that the as-prepared Bi2Se3 can function as a new photothermal nanomaterial for PTT.
In order to achieve effectively targeted photothermal ablation of tumor cells, Huang's group designed Cu2-xSe NPs based nanocomposites for combined treatment [132]. Cu2-xSe NPs was firstly synthesized by the reaction of Se NPs as a template with CuS solution [133]. Later, positively-charged poly(allylamine) hydrochloride (PAH) was used to modify Cu2-xSe, and then negatively charged GO as a photosensitizer was covered on Cu2-xSe by electrostatic interaction. Moreover, a recognition molecule for targeting tumor cells with receptors of folic acid was covalently linked onto the surface of Cu2-xSe/rGO via amide reaction between the carboxyl groups of folic acid and the amine groups of PAH. Therefore, the final nanocomposite combined folic acid receptor mediated targeting, DOX mediated chemotherapy, and Cu2-xSe and rGO photothermal therapy together to effectively kill tumor cells.

sections.heading: 2.5. Organic molecules-based nanomaterials
sections.text: In addition to the inorganic nanomaterials, self-assembly of organic molecules attracted great attention for obtaining various PTT agents due to the possibility of precise molecular structure control [107,134,135]. Meanwhile, the obtained functional organic nanomaterials could enhance the water solubility, biocompatibility, and dispersibility. To date, organic PTT agents mainly include NIR dyes and conductive polymer nanomaterials [136,137].

sections.heading: 2.5.1. NIR dyess
sections.text:
NIR dyes, such as indocyanine green (ICG), not only exhibit efficient photothermal property and bio-safety but also can act as fluorescent imaging probes for imaging-guided PTT [138,139]. ICG, a tricarbocyanine dye, exhibits absorption and emission maxima in the NIR region around 740 and 800 nm, respectively [140]. It is the only organic NIR dye approved by the U.S. Food and Drug Administration for human medical imaging and diagnosis in clinical applications [141]. Intriguing by this, many researchers developed photothermal conversion materials containing ICG NPs. Ma and co-workers constructed a biodegradable nanotheranostic agent for fluorescence/magnetic resonance dual-modal imaging-guided PTT [142]. To be specific, superparamagnetic iron oxide (SPIO) NPs were firstly coated by 1,2‑distearoyl‑sn‑glycero‑3‑phosphoethanolamine‑N‑methoxy (polyethylene glycol) (DSPE-PEG) to obtain the SPIO@DSPE-PEG NPs. Then the ICG molecules were loaded onto SPIO@DSPE-PEG NPs. The final SPIO@ DSPE-PEG NPs were well-dispersed in water with an average hydrodynamic diameter of 29.9 nm. It was found that the temperature elevated rapidly under the NIR light. At the ICG concentration of 4.32 μg/ mL, sample solutions were heated up to 42 °C from 21.6 °C [143].
By combining PTT, photodynamic therapy, and MR imaging, Cai et al. fabricated a multifunctional theranostic using ironIII-based metalorganic frameworks (Fe-soc-MOF), whose surface was modified by ICG and polyethylene glycol (FPINs, Fig. 8A) [144]. The stability of ICG was enhanced by the carrier, Fe-soc-MOF, which efficiently avoided ICG degradation in aqueous solution. The monodispersed Fe-soc-MOF NPs were fabricated through the liquid-solid solution method. For detailed information, sodium oleate, FeCl3, and oleic acid were mixed in 1.0mL of water and vigorously stirred at 50 °C for 30min. Then DMSO contained H4-ABTC and triethylamine were added to the mixture. The solution was heated up to 120 °C and held for 2 h to obtain Fe-soc-MOF NPs. Finally, ICG was conjugated to the surface of Fe-soc-MOF to form photosensitizer. As shown in Fig. 8B, the diameter of the FPINs was
about 100 nm. Results showed that the temperature of the FPINs aqueous solution rapidly increased to about 75 °C in 5min under the NIR irradiation. The photothermal conversion efficiency of FPINs aqueous solution was calculated only to be 25.3%. This low-efficiency value could be ascribed to the small amount of ICG grafted on the surface of Fe-soc-MOF. However, the tumor volume was efficiently inhibited in the FPINs+NIR group. This antitumor efficacy indicated that FPINs could be considered as an effective photosensitizer to kill the tumor cell.

sections.heading: 2.5.2. Conductive polymers
sections.text:
Conductive polymers, such as polypyrrole, polyaniline, and poly (3,4 ethylenedioxythiophene), have been widely used in biomedical engineering fields such as artificial organs [146], biosensors [147], and others. They are more cost-efficient than noble metal nanomaterials and exhibit better biocompatibility than inorganic nanomaterials. Thus, conductive polymer NPs are promising agents for PTT method [148]. However, the desired dispersity and targeting efficiency are difficult to be fulfilled by un-modified conductive polymers, which are hydrophobic and have a few reactive groups for functional modification. Therefore, the development of conductive polymer NPs with abundant functional groups is of vital importance.
To achieve this, Bi et al. fabricated homogenous BSA‑poly(pyrrole‑3-carboxylic acid) (PPyCOOH) NPs via a reverse microemulsion method [149]. Briefly, 5.84 g of sodium dodecyl sulfate was added into a mixture of 50mL n‑heptane and 11mL n‑butyl alcohol. Kepping the solution under stirring for 20min, 8mL PyCOOH aqueous solution (4mg/mL) and 60mg ferrous chloride tetrahydrate were added to the mixture in order. After magnetic stirring for 30min, 68.5mg ammonium persulfate was mixed with the above solution and the resultant solution was stirred for 12 h. After centrifugation and washing, PPyCOOH NPs with a diameter of 20–30 nm were obtained. Furthermore, 30mg EDC and NHS were dissolved in 5mL PPyCOOH NPs (2mg/mL) aqueous dispersions under magnetic stirring at room temperature for 2 h. After removing the solvent, 5 mL BSA aqueous solution was added dropwise into the solution and held for 6 h. Finally, the BSA-PPyCOOH NPs with a primary hydrodynamic size of 32 nm were successfully fabricated. Similar to polypyrrole, the BSA-PPyCOOH NPs showed obvious absorbance in the NIR region. Moreover, the photothermal conversion efficiency of the BSA-modified PPyCOOH NPs was calculated to be 40.8%. This efficiency was even higher than that of many inorganic photothermal agents, such as CuS (16.3%) [150].
To improve photothermal conversion efficiency, Liu et al. synthesized a novel phototherapeutic agent of aza-BDP based conductive
polymer (IABDP), which exhibited high NIR absorption and excellent photostability [145]. The synthetic route of IABDP was shown in Fig. 8C and D mainly by the self-assembling method. In detail, this platform introduced two hydrophilic triethylene‑glycol chains to offer hydrophilic units, further these amphipathic molecular could self-assemble into nanoparticles by solvophobic interactions. The as-prepared photothermal agent of IABDP NPs with a size of 200 nm. Under NIR irradiation for 5min (64 μg/mL of IABDP, 635 nm, 0.8W/cm2), the photothermal conversion efficiency was calculated to be 54%. Therefore, this was proposed to be a potential agent for tumor treatment.

sections.heading: 2.6. Summary
sections.text:
In the above sections, we introduced and discussed the fabrications and characterizations for the nanomaterials that can be used as
photosensitizers. To make it more clear, here we present a table (Table 1) to illustrate the photothermal conversion ability of noble metal-, carbon-, semiconductor- and organic-based nanomaterials.

sections.heading: 3. Photothermal materials for tumor therapy
sections.text:
Photothermal materials are used for tumor treatment such as PTT, photodynamic therapy, and controlled release of drugs [152]. To be specific, Photodynamic therapy employs the singlet oxygen or reactive oxygen species generated from photosensitizer molecules under light exposure to kill tumor cells [153]. While PTT utilizes photothermal materials to generate heat from NIR light in order to kill tumor cells. Advanced strategies for improving the PTT outcomes via laser dosage and imaging techniques, as well as increasing photothermal conversion efficiency and the accumulation of PTAs in tumors can be found in the
L, D, T are the abbreviation of length, diameter and thickness, respectively.
review of Liu et al. [154]. Aiming at improving the efficiency, combination therapy, such as image-guided PTT and chemo-PTT, are achieved via chemical/physical modification of photosensitizers.

sections.heading: 3.1. Hyperthermia for PTT
sections.text:
Hyperthermia is a method utilized to kill tumor cells through temperature increase to 40–43 °C at the tumor sites [163]. It is an adjunctive therapy with various established tumor treatments like chemotherapy and radiotherapy [164]. Abundant of research showed that PTT is an effective method to achieve hyperthermia upon NIR irradiation. For example, Li and colleagues synthesized CuS NPs via wet chemistry, and the as-prepared CuS NPs could be used as photosensitizers to cause cell death by photothermal effect under NIR irradiation [18].
Via chemical/physical modifications in a galvanic replacement reaction as Wang reported [165], through the galvanic replacement reaction between Ag NPs and AuIII to fabricated Au NPs, then organic molecule was conjugated onto the surface of Au NPs via specific chemical bonding like Au-S. Ma et al. synthesized hollow and spike-like gold nanostructures (GNSs) by this method (Fig. 9B) [155]. Owing to the modification of thiol-terminated monomethoxy poly(ethylene glycol) (HS-PEG) via the thiol-gold coupling, the as-prepared PEGylated GNSs with low cytotoxicity. Results showed that the GNSs exhibited high photothermal conversion efficiency (50.3%) under NIR laser irradiations. Moreover, the GNSs mediated PTT method reduced the cell survival fraction to 89%, but the PTT alone was to 97%. (Fig. 9C). These phenomena might be attributed to the hyperthermia induced by GNSs, which possessed excellent photothermal property.
NIR-photothermal properties were also achieved by chemically exfoliated MoS2 (ceMoS2) nanosheets. Chou and co-workers prepared this ceMoS2 via Morrison method [157,158]. This method breaks the weak interlayer forces in bulk MoS2 through ultrasonication and the formation of H2 gas. The resulted ceMoS2 nanosheets presented size of 800 nm and a thickness of 1.54 nm. The NIR absorbance of the asprepared ceMoS2 nanosheets, 29.2 L/(g−×cm)−, was 7.8 times over the NIR absorbance of GO.
As was reported, NIR induced locoregional hyperthermia PTT is a relatively safe method for tumor therapy. The temperature of tumor cells can be adjusted by the location and the intensity of NIR irradiation. Therefore, the normal organs won't be affected or only have very little damage. Besides, this method possesses low toxicity, even when associated with other therapies [163].

sections.heading: 3.2. Imaging-guided PTT
sections.text:
To detect the distribution of photosensitizers and assess photothermal therapy performance, real-time imaging techniques play a more and more important role in tumor therapy [166]. Recently, photoacoustic (PA) imaging was considered as a novel and promising alternative for tumor cell imaging. Specifically, the NIR light can be used to induce the photothermal effect of photosensitizers and thus accomplish the PA-guided PTT [167]. Attributed to the photothermal effect, the thermal signals, which produced by thermal expansion or bubble formation of photosensitizers, can be converted into imaging information.
Wang and co-workers synthesized an amphiphilic redox-responsive NIR boron-dipyrromethenes (BODIPY)-based dye, as shown in Fig. 10A. The key to dye formation came from the BODIPY-based NPs and glutathione (GSH) self-assembly [162]. The diameter of BODIPY-based NPs was appr. 80 nm. Moreover, PEG and BODIPY were linked together through the redox-sensitive disulfide bond, which could accelerate the dissociation of NPs to turn on the NIR fluorescence. It was demonstrated that the location and temperature information were tracked via real-time imaging. In the process, BODIPY-based dyes were injected into mice, which were infected with tumor intratumorally. After 12 h,
the PA signal was obviously observed in the tumor sites (Fig. 10B). In the next step, the redox-responsive NIR BODIPY-based NPs solution was intravenously injected into mice, as Fig. 10C. The intensity of NIR fluorescence in tumor sites reached the maximum after 36 h. Then it gradually receded and was observed to be high in the liver and other organs. These observations indicated that the NIR fluorescence firstly appeared in the whole body, later accumulated in tumor sites, demonstrated from the NIR fluorescence image.
In another example, Li et al. developed a NIR fluorescence probe (PF) to use as fluorescent and photosensitizers simultaneously [160]. This PF was composed of functional 7‑dimethylamino flavylium heptamethine dye (FS) and the amphiphilic polypeptide of P(OEGMA)21-P (Asp)16 by conjugating the small-molecule NIR fluorophore of FS with amphiphilic polypeptide of P(OEGMA)21-P(Asp)16. The final PF with a diameter of 90 nm in aqueous solution and exhibited a negative charge of −12.5mV. Importantly, the PF showed prominent photothermal conversion efficiency of 42.3%. In vivo study demonstrated that the PF was accumulated at the tumor site effectively because of the enhanced permeability and retention, which could be visualized by NIR fluorescence imaging and further was very helpful for image-guided PTT.
The fact that PA imaging-guided photothermal therapy can improve the efficiency of single photothermal therapy, points to the ability of real-time temperature information at the tumor sites and in the whole body. Therefore, the tumor cells could be killed more effectively and accurately. Meanwhile, the position of the NIR irradiation can be better determined for the operators.

sections.heading: 3.3. Chemo-PTT
sections.text:
Directing in strengthening the tumor cell therapy, combined methods have been developed, such as chemo-PTT. Photosensitizers, which was decorated with drug molecular like DOX, was used for generating temperature evolution and the drug molecular to kill tumor cells. At the same time, heat energy can accelerate the motion of drug molecular [168]. For instance, Cheng et al. designed a nanosystem (Fig. 10D), which composed of the selenous acid (H2SeO3) and a phasechange material (PCM) of lauric acid loaded in Au nanocages (AuNCPCM-H2SeO3) [156]. Owing to the solid structure of PCM, the limited release of H2SeO3 from the AuNC-PCM-H2SeO3 (1.19mg/mL) solution was observed at 37 °C. Upon NIR laser irradiation (808 nm at a power of 0.8W/cm2) for 25min, the temperature of the AuNC-PCM-H2SeO3 solution elevated to 44 °C. Meanwhile, the concentration of H2SeO3 increased to 72mg/mL. The study confirmed that this chemo-PTT could significantly enhance the destruction of tumor cells.
Another promising direction is PTT accompanying with drug delivery. You and co-workers designed a co-delivery nanosystem for two drugs as chemo-PTT [161]. As illustrated in Fig. 11A, 2‑(4‑aminophenyl) benzothiazole molecule-cholesterol derivative (CC) was synthesized by coupling the CJM-COOH molecule with cholesterol through the bridging effect of malonyl dichloride. Then CC loaded with Pt and modified by FA (CC-Pt@FA) NPs was fabricated by a film hydration method. The diameter of the as-prepared NPs was about 103 nm. Then, the thermal imaging profiles detected by Infrared Camera were observed from the CC-Pt@FA-NPs suspension with ICG of 50 μmol/L under NIR laser (808 nm, 1.54W) for 5min. Its temperature variation was shown in Fig. 11B. In addition, the NIR responsive release of ICG and CJM126 in CC-Pt@FA-NPs solutions was investigated and shown in
Fig. 11C, so as to simulate the normal tissue environment (pH=7.4). The release efficiencies of Pt and CJM126 were 11.49% and 6.96% respectively. However, they increased to 96.65% and 51.81%, respectively, when exposed under the NIR laser over 24 h. Moreover, the MDA-MB-231 cell viability was only at 3.05% after 24 h, attributing to the remarkable inhibitory effect of the NPs on cell proliferation (Fig. 11D). It was assumed that the cytotoxicity of Pt was reduced by the liposome shell structure, as well as ICG provide the photothermal ability to the system. Therefore, this nanosystem exhibited great

potential as a photothermal agent for synergetic tumor therapy. Furthermore, chemodynamic therapy (CDT) has been regarded as a highly specific tumor therapy approach which removes tumor cells by the cytotoxic hydroxyl radicals (·OH) that produced by mental ions catalysis. Wu et al. recently developed Fe(III) species-WS2-polyvinypyrrolidone(Fe(III)@WS2-PVP) nanocapsules by one-pot synthesis. [159] The ammonium tetrathiotungstate (H8N2S4W), ferric chloride hexahydrate (FeCl3·6H2O), and PVP solution were treated and then loaded with DOX to realize the combination of augmented tumor nanocatalytic, chemotherapy and PTT. It was expected that Fe(III) species could lead to the rolling-up of WS2 nanosheets, and the formation of the nanocapsules with abundant inner space could enhance the DOX loading capacity. Meanwhile, the endogenous redox reaction between Fe(III) species and WS2 nanosheets could transform the Fe(III)@WS2PVP nanocapsules to nontoxic Fe2+ and WO42−, and the formed Fe2+ could be oxidized to Fe3+ to further react with Fe(III)@WS2-PVP nanocapsules. It was found that this repetitive endogenous redox reaction played an important role in the continuous Fe2+ generation and biodegradation of Fe(III) @ WS2-PVP nanocapsules as well as the DOX release. What's more, the continuously-generated Fe2+ could trigger a fast Fenton reaction with the innate overexpressed H2O2 under the mild acidic tumor microenvironment in tumor cells, producing abundant highly cytotoxic %OH to enable the nanocatalytic tumor CDT. In particular, it was demonstrated that the as-prepared Fe(III)@WS2-PVP nanocapsules possessed a long-time stability. When DOX concentration was set as 100 μg/mL, the drug loading efficiency of Fe(III)@WS2-PVP nanocapsules (1000 μg/mL) and WS2-PVP nanosheets (1000 μg/mL)
were determined as 97.9 ± 4.0 and 90.7 ± 0.8% (p < 0.05), respectively. In addition, they found that the tumor volume of untreated mice increased by 8.5 times in 28 days. However, the tumor volume of mice receiving Fe(III)@WS2-PVP nanocapsules injection increased by 6.2 times in 28 days. If irradiated the mice which was injected with Fe (III)@WS2-PVP nanocapsules by 808 nm laser, the tumor volume increased 2.9 times. Encouragingly, the tumor volume increased by only 1.3 times while the DOX-loaded Fe(III)@WS2-PVP nanocapsules were injected to mice, which proved that the as-synthesized DOX-loaded Fe (III)@WS2-PVP nanocapsules could achieve excellent synergistic treatment with CDT, PTT and chemotherapy.
Chemo-PTT is becoming an assignable method for tumor therapy. The heat energy generated by PTT not only increased the temperature around tumor cells but also accelerated the motion of drug molecular. This dual-effect significantly accelerated the death of tumor cells and controlled the severe side effect of drugs to the normal tissue.

sections.heading: 4. Conclusions and outlooks
sections.text:
PTT has become a new generation of effective treatment for the tumor, due to its non-invasive and weak side effects. In this review, the current developments of nanomaterials as photothermal agents for tumor therapy are summarized as shown in the Table 2. In general, the metal-, carbon-, semiconductor-, and organic-based nanomaterials performed both high photothermal conversion efficiency and safety for normal cells. These photothermal nanomaterials were systematically introduced in this review form fabrication, characterization, to
η: represent of the value of photothermal conversion efficiency.
applications. Besides, the mechanisms of photosensitizers were described in detail, which mainly included, i, the accumulation of photosensitizers in the tumor sites, ii,adsorption of NIR light by these photosensitizers , and iii, thermal ablation of tumor cells locally. It was demonstrated that nanomaterials acted as good bridges between NIR light and tumor killing.
In the near future, PTT will continue to play an essential role in clinical applications and require numerous efforts into the related scientific researches. Firstly, physical and chemical modifications provided photosensitizers high photothermal conversion efficiency and good biocompatibility. Secondly, light-actuated nanomaterials facilitated rapid, remote control, and adjustable NPs movements. Thirdly, PTT was combined with other tumor therapy for efficiently removing tumor cells without severe damage to adjacent normal tissues. Moreover, designing dual-effect tumor therapies is of vital importance for various functions, such as drug delivery, real-time imaging, and chem-PTT.
Despite impressing signs of progress in developing photothermal nanomaterials, a number of challenges still remain toward clinical applications. Biocompatible, long-term toxicity, dose-dependent toxicity, target-specificity, and biodegradation, etc., are still problems to be solved. Notably, the potential threats of photosensitizers to patients and environments should not be ignored. Practically, it was believed that this review provides valuable information on novel photosensitizers fabrications and will inspire researchers to dedicate more efforts in PTT methods.

metadata.abstractText: Currently, a lot of efforts have been applied to diagnosis and treat tumors through the fabrication of highlyefficient and multi-functional nanomaterials. Superior to other methods, photothermal therapy (PTT) has been demonstrated as a noninvasive, controllable, and targeted strategy to eliminate tumor cells. The use of functional biomedical and bioactive nanomaterials can enhance the photothermal performances and meanwhile integrate with favorable functions, by taking into account their risk assessments. In this review, novel engineered photothermal nanomaterials, such as noble metal-, carbon-, semiconductor-, and organic molecule-based PTT agents, as well as their targeted biomedical applications were summarized and discussed comprehensively. Particularly, the latest advances of not only the conventional nanomaterials, but also the newly-discovered alternatives, like Au-Ag, graphdiyne, and selenides, were introduced. Besides the benefits, the risks and other implications of novel PTT agents were recorded and evaluated. Moreover, the potential applications of nanomaterials in targeted and multi-functional PTT treatments, which served as foundations and directions for future PTT approaches developments, were stated. Depending on the urgency and boosting demands for tumor treatments, novel engineering advancements of techniques, not limited to PTT and nanomaterials, are prerequisites in the history of medical development.
